section.title: Practice : samba authentication
section.para: 0. Make sure you have properly named backups of your smb.conf of the previous practices.
1. Create three users (on the Linux and on the samba), remember their passwords!
2. Set up a shared directory that is only accessible to authenticated users.
3. Use smbclient and a windows computer to access your share, use more than one user account (windows requires a logoff/logon for this).
4. Verify that files created by these users belong to them.
5. Try to change or delete a file from another user.

section.title: Solution: samba authentication
section.para: 1. Create three users (on the Linux and on the samba), remember their passwords!
2. Set up a shared directory that is only accessible to authenticated users.
section.screen: The shared section in smb.conf could look like this:
[authwrite] path = /srv/samba/authwrite comment = authenticated users only read only = no guest ok = no
section.para: 3. Use smbclient and a windows computer to access your share, use more than one user account (windows requires a logoff/logon for this).
section.screen: on windows net use p: \\studentX\authwrite password /user:user2
section.para: 4. Verify that files created by these users belong to them.
5. Try to change or delete a file from another user.
section.screen: you should not be able to change or overwrite files from others.
